descriptions.content:
The particle གིས་ must be used with ergative verbs in the perfective past. However, the particle is often omitted in the present (or past imperfective) and future.

  • རང་ག་རེ་བྱེད་ཀྱི་ཡོད། “What are you doing?”
  • ཨ་མ་ལགས་མཆོད་ཆང་མཆོད་ཀྱི་རེད་པས། “Will your mother have some beer?”

However, it reappears if the speaker is either stressing the agent or if the latter is being contrastively emphasized.

  • ཁོང་གསོལ་ཇ་བཟོ་གི་ཡོད་རེད། “He’s making tea.”
  • གོང་གིས་གསོལ་ཇ་བཟོ་གི་ཡོད་རེད། “He’s making the tea. (I’m making momos.)”

In cases where the ergative marker is omitted, the agentive function is simply indicated by word order: the grammatical agent comes first, while the patient figures just before the verb.

  • ང་ཁྱེད་རང་དྲན་གྱིས། “I remember you.” (This is also the usual way of saying “I miss you!”)
  • ཁྱེད་རང་ང་དྲན་གྱི་འདུག་གས། “Do you remember me?”

In both these examples the agentive particle could of course be inserted; this would have the effect of emphasizing the agent.

  • ང་ཁྱེད་རང་དྲན་གྱིས། “I remember you.”

When the agent is shifted to occupy the position just before the verb, it usually carries a case marker.

  • ཁྱེད་རང་ངས་དྲན་གྱིས། “You, I remember.”

The ergative marker is not usually used with volitional intransitive verbs (notably verbs of motion), but it may appear with verbs in this category if the subject is being emphatically contrasted with another.

  • ང་གནས་མཇལ་ལ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན། “I went on a pilgrimage.”
  • ངས་གནས་མཇལ་ལ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན། “I went on a pilgrimage. (They went trading.)”

By contrast, it should be remembered that the ergative never occurs with non-volitional intransitive verbs.
